content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Very cool clash.
The description is clear.
Everything works.
Difficulty is perfect.
Awesome!

Cool clash.
Everything checks out for me.
As a suggestion you should avoid submitting your solution in a golf style, it makes it very difficult to verify, especially if you are not familiar with JS.
Some suggestions :
...in the randomly generated sequence... ➔ ...in a randomly generated sequence...
There is 8 (2^3) possible bit sequences... ➔ There are 8 (2^3) possible bit sequences...  
...finding a sequence of 11 in the sequence of 3 random bits. ➔  ...finding the sequence "11" in a sequence of 3 random bits.   ( clearer this way I think)

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Nice contribution. Difficulty is good for CoC, I like how the 0 length case makes shortest code more interesting.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: In addition to being a lot of fun, you can solve it in several ways.
I didn't try to make a short code, but I really liked your solution :)

I've revisited description and improved it slightly. So thank you for your suggestions, they were very helpful.
I'm not gonna change solution rn tho, I'm lazy. Maybe later

ooooh, thank you!
I'm really glad

Well, the possibility of finding "0" in the "" is 0 so my test is fine I think.
Thanks for pointing that out tho. I like that the toString(2) approach will have some difficulty since it's the most intuitive one for generating possible sequences.
I'll assume that you were able to understand everything else so I'll move this puzzle from WIP to Ready.
And I strongly urge you to use `regex.test(str)` instead of `(str.match(regex)||[]).length>0`.
I even used regex.test (str), but it got an error and I was too lazy to check :P
I could use several other things, like indexOf, includes, split (as you did). I used regex because I started studying a few weeks ago and I want to use as many clash as possible
Oh, it's all ok then. You scared me for a moment
